title: Addiction & Compulsion
subtitle: Understanding and working with what you can't stop
description: Addictions and compulsions are attempts to meet real needs through harmful means. This course helps you understand the function of your addictive patterns, address underlying needs, and build genuine alternatives. Not a replacement for clinical treatment of severe addiction.

modules.description: What addiction is and why willpower doesn't work

modules.title: The Function of Your Pattern
modules.description: What need is this behavior trying to meet?

modules.title: Nervous System and Addiction
modules.description: The regulation role of addictive behaviors

modules.title: Working with Cravings

whatYouLearn: Identify the real need beneath your pattern
See the nervous system role in compulsive behavior
Work skillfully with cravings and urges
Build genuine alternatives that meet real needs
Approach recovery with compassion rather than shame
requirements: Willingness to examine your patterns honestly
This course is for mild-moderate patterns; severe addiction requires clinical support
Therapist or recovery program recommended for substance addiction

questions.question: Why doesn't willpower alone work for addiction?
options: Addiction involves brain circuits, nervous system regulation, and unmet needs—not just choice

questions.question: What 'function' might an addiction be serving?
options: Regulating emotions, numbing pain, creating connection, or meeting other legitimate needs

questions.question: What is the nervous system's role in addiction?
options: Addictive behaviors often serve to regulate an overwhelmed or depleted nervous system

questions.question: What is a helpful approach when cravings arise?
options: Acknowledge the craving, get curious about the underlying need, and use alternatives

questions.question: Why is finding alternatives important?
options: Real needs don't disappear—they need to be met through healthier means
To replace one addiction with another

questions.question: Why is self-compassion important in recovery?
options: It's not—you need to be hard on yourself
Shame fuels addiction; compassion supports nervous system regulation and sustainable change
